page_analysis.text_content:
Daylight plane

The daylight plane in conjunction with the setbacks & height limits, create an invisible tent

intended to contain development on the lot in a way that preserves privacy and exposure to natural light.

Code sections
Page 26
18.12.040 (a) Table 2
Page 27
18.04
Page 28
18.12.040 (c) Table 2
Page 29
18.12.050 (b) (2)
18.12.040 (i)

Primary daylight plane (sides)

The primary daylight plane regulates structures located within the buildable area. Structures located in the rear and/or side yards are regulated by the accessory-structure daylight plan described on the next page.

Fig 20 Front elevation showing side primary daylight plane

Max. allowed is Min. required by Building Code

45°

10' from average grade

Average grade

Grade at the nearest point on the adjacent lot

Existing grade of the structure (at midpoint of wall)

side lot line

24' max. for protrusions

Max. building height

side lot line

Notes:

• Daylight plane is measured from average grade.

• Average grade is established using existing grade—before any grading or fill (See Fig 44 p. 42)

• Side daylight plane is measured (up) at lot line.

• Rear daylight plane is measured (up) at rear setback.

visual_elements.description: Front elevation drawing of a house showing the side primary daylight plane with dashed lines forming an angled plane at 45 degrees from a point 10 feet above average grade at the side lot line. The diagram includes labels for average grade, grade at the nearest point on the adjacent lot, existing grade of the structure at midpoint of wall, maximum allowed height per building code, 24 feet max for protrusions, and max building height. Vertical arrows indicate height measurements and horizontal arrows indicate distances. The side lot line is marked on both sides of the house.
3D wireframe illustration of an invisible tent shape representing the daylight plane concept, located in the left sidebar.

technical_specifications.parameter: Height from average grade for daylight plane start

additional_notes: Text is clear and legible with no quality issues.
The left sidebar contains a shaded background with white text and a 3D wireframe graphic illustrating the daylight plane concept.
Notes section provides clarifications on how measurements are taken.
References a figure on another page: 'See Fig 44 p. 42'.
